review:
I don‚Äôt usually play games on my phone. It‚Äôs been years since I have ever actually sat down for more than 20 minutes to play a game on my phone. I‚Äôve haven‚Äôt played many games like Genshin Impact. The ones I have were rather boring or just weren‚Äôt very compatible with a smartphone. 
This is my first review of any app or game, and this game is worthy of it. It surprised me greatly how the developers have created controls and game physics that just seem to work very well on mobile. Sure there are some minor inconveniences occasionally with movement, but generally those can be fixed by simply playing on a tablet or larger screen. Better yet, it would be a fantastic idea for this game to have control compatibility. 
The graphics style are beautiful for a smartphone and revolutionize their platform. 
On to gameplay, this game takes the cake. It has very enjoyable combat systems and loot systems that are very fair. Getting new characters and opening item packs won‚Äôt cost you anything if you simply grind for a while. The prices are fair for packs and the loot itself has very interesting and unique designs. 
Fighting in the game is very fun, though at times it may seem repetitive. I‚Äôve played the game for about 2-3 hours in total if I were to guess, so perhaps combat may become even more difficult as I progress. The unique abilities each character has are fun to use and combine to demolish your enemies. 
The story and characters were the most surprising enjoyment I had. I actually do like the characters. They have some personality to them and break up the pace of the game. I get a good chuckle here and there as I play. The quests have cool stories with endings I don‚Äôt expect and the locations are quite interesting in design.
The map is HUGE and contains many areas where players can get loot and explore. 

Overall, I‚Äôm having a blast with this game and you might too if your in search of BoTW type games. My biggest recommendation for developers is to add controller compatibility. I can anticipate that if that is implemented right, this game might just hit #1 on the charts if it isn‚Äôt there already. I don‚Äôt have a PS4 so playing it on console isn‚Äôt an option. But i still quite enjoy this game, and plan to continue to play it for a while.
title: One of the few games of its genre I have ever enjoyed

review:
Really really nice game, includes a combo mechanic similar to Honkai Impact 3 but has much more freedom due to not being restricted to scenario/arena battles also. The elemental combos are a nice touch, used to solve open world and dungeon puzzles, reminds me a bit of a lite golden sun and definitely of zelda. 

One drawback i see so far is the camera i think it‚Äôs a bit too close, restricts the view on iphone which makes you more reliant on adjusting camera (and the world is gorgeous so it‚Äôs a shame). Zooming out seems to revert to closer angle after a run or if in front of something restricting the view. The joystick also compounds the problem as it‚Äôs a bit too close to the center of the screen (when walking forward my finger is almost at the midway of top/bottom screen). Hopefully a way to reposition the joystick will be introduced. 

The last minor thing is the aiming button (with a ranged character) i think would be much better on the left side of the screen, as camera positioning also positions the aim and currently you have to stop moving camera go into aimed mode and start moving camera again making it a bit less fluid. If on the left side though you would aim with left thumb, already having stopped walking/running to do so, while you aim with the right thumb so you can then fire faster with the left side fire button. These are just minor things im sure can be worked on, either way there‚Äôs a pc version too where the bigger screen would be fantastic!!!

Overall awesome game though, highly reccomend!

title: Zhongli

review:
I play this game on PS4 (AR 45), but it‚Äôs so addicting that I find myself downloading it on my phone just so I can start a new file and play when I‚Äôm not at home.

I remember the 75 hours or so I put into Zelda: Breath of the Wild and despite playing it for so long, my reaction to everything I found was generally the same: ‚ÄúEh. S‚Äôokay.‚Äù I remember asking myself how a world can be so open and look so vibrant and somehow be so... underwhelming at the same time. As a longtime Zelda fan, I remember the disappointment very clearly. The trying and trying to force myself to like it because it was Zelda and just not being able to. Other people could and that‚Äôs great, but I felt like I only got half the game that was pitched to me.

Genshin Impact turned out to be the game experience I was looking for in BotW. The sheer amount of things to do. Actually being rewarded with something other than a Korok for exploring thoroughly. The actual STORY that plays out. I don‚Äôt have to look for memories. I get to experience the events of the story AS they‚Äôre happening.

This game was pitched to me as ‚Äúit‚Äôs basically Breath of the Wild, but with actual stuff to do‚Äù, and by golly they were right. At first I almost felt affronted; to say that the visual is a rip-off of BotW is kind of understating it, as well as the premise of the story‚Äôs hero falling into a long slumber during wartime and awakening hundreds of years later. A mostly silent protagonist. Open world puzzles. And again, the landscape and colors are so similar I‚Äôm surprised they haven‚Äôt been sued. However while it is visually (and at the start, narratively) similar to BotW, the similarities do end rather quickly. The colors are more vibrant, the characters are more interesting. And the story is nothing like Zelda‚Äôs.

To say nothing of the gameplay. The battle system is fun and intuitive. Harnessing and combining different elements to deal insane damage. FUN exploration. A different play style for every character. Leveling up weapons (that don‚Äôt break!) and artifacts that will further boost your characters‚Äô stats. It‚Äôs all very fun!

There are some drawbacks of course. This is a free-to-play mobile/console game. Certain activities require stamina to claim rewards for (this won‚Äôt really slow you down at first, but it becomes more crucial to be frugal with it the higher your level climbs, and it takes about 5 min to recharge 1 stamina) and beyond the first four characters, every character can only be played after pulling them from the gacha system. The rates aren‚Äôt the worst I‚Äôve ever experienced, but they‚Äôre not fantastic either. I have all but one four star character, and the one five star character I‚Äôve pulled was because I hit the 90 roll pity limit. But this doesn‚Äôt really hold me back as I have a lot of variety to choose from with my normal characters (though I do realize not everyone is as lucky). Sometimes the loading takes a while. And you will notice texture pops. There are drawbacks, but I don‚Äôt feel that they‚Äôre annoying enough to knock a star off my rating.

I could go on forever. I love the game, the lore is accessible and not boring, and the characters can be one-note but are endearing nonetheless. It‚Äôs a more fun and engaging play than Breath of the Wild, and as long as you have self-control it won‚Äôt make you bleed money. Check it out! You have nothing to lose.
title: Breath of the Wild done right

review: To begin this review I will announce that on the date of November 20, 2020, I am Adventure Rank 43. If you do not know what that means, it means I am fairly deep into the game. The first few hours of this game, let‚Äôs say a day‚Äôs worth, 24hrs total, this game feels amazing, opportunity in every direction, a feeling of freedom. Once you use all up the game‚Äôs starter phase and are well experienced the game gradually starts closing their gates on you the further and further you progress. They do this by using an action limiting currency well known to the community as Resin. Commonly known as ‚ÄúEnergy, Stamina, Lives, Chances, or Uses‚Äù in many other games. Once you hit Adventure Rank 30 you really start to see how limited things are. A beautiful open world game such as this one. A game where you want to feel free and have fun with your friends. Right now, I hate to say it, but this is not that game. At least not until they accept that their system is flawed and make changes. No, not small changes like raising the resin cap. This is what they do about everyone filling them in about their issue. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre listening‚Äù many say, but are they really? If they were actually listening and not trying to swipe every penny from your wallet then they‚Äôd actually make heavy changes that we as the community can be satisfied with. You need resin for just about anything you do in this game. Need character exp? Resin. Need Character Evolution Material? Well guess what, that‚Äôs a separate part of gaining exp. More Resin. Need Weapon Exp? Oh, Resin. Need Mora (In game currency or gold) to upgrade your equipment and characters? Resin. You need to get better equipment for your character? You know what comes next! Resin. You need exclusive material from a once a week boss? Triple the Resin. Yes, once a week. In fact they‚Äôve even added a new system called the reputation system! It sounded great... until it came out. Whilst this does not use Resin, it is also, guess! Action - Limited. Once a week, and you can clear it in less than 30min. So, take this all in. They don‚Äôt give you enough Resin to get enough resources or even to just play the game for enjoyment. They gate you so hard on everything to halt your progress that it is impossible to enjoy the game and it instead just becomes a daily task. Right now, it‚Äôs not looking good. I don‚Äôt want to say this but what it LOOKS like is that this company MiHoYo just wants your money, and does not actually care about what we as the community are saying. This doesn‚Äôt have to be. Fix the resin. I‚Äôd even be happier with rarer drop rates than having to use resin to claim rewards from literally anything meaningful in this game. Boss drops, dungeon loot, Mora, exp. At least it‚Äôd give me a reason to play. A reason to spend time with friends in this game, grinding for some good loot, which right now is actually kind of pointless. Logging on for 10-15 minutes to clear a dungeon and your daily commissions. If I had plans to play with my friends I‚Äôd sure hope it‚Äôs longer than some measly 10-15 minutes. Co-op isn‚Äôt looking too hot either. All of this excludes the early game. The early game is gold and what this game should be by default. Play this game a while and you‚Äôll see what I‚Äôm talking about. Have you ever heard of an open world that gates every inch of progression? I have, it‚Äôs called Genshin Impact. Two stars or less until they fix their issue. No one wants to play an open world to play an action-limit game. Two stars for thier... well, I can‚Äôt stress this enough, ACTION LIMITING SYSTEMS and how the game makes me feel as the player. Late game, do I want to play this? Yes, but how it is? No. It‚Äôs more of a daily 10-15 minute hassle/chore than an hour or more of enjoyment. That‚Äôs why I want to play it. To enjoy it freely. Not to play and have the game tell me, oh sorry you can‚Äôt pick that flower anymore, you‚Äôve used up all of your chances. You might have also heard this word as well... Gacha? Ha! I haven‚Äôt even spoken about gacha. Anyways. Five amazing stars for Graphics, voice actors, storyline, animation, and special effects.

review:
Everything in this game is extremely well thought out and incredibly easy to understand. And not in a hand-holding way either. 

 The game encourages you to venture out on your own to forge your own individual adventure. Even with set missions and scripted events no two people will have the same experience. Building your own team isn‚Äôt even the start of it, as just generally walking in a different direction than someone else will give you an entirely different experience. I‚Äôve uncovered many mini bosses and battles simply by practicing my gliding across the mountains or picking ingredients. And the rewards for even the simplest tasks are insanely satisfying. You truly feel like you‚Äôve accomplished something. 

Saying the game is open world is an understatement. The amount of variety in the terrain, landscape, enemies, npcs, dungeons, battles, etc in every zone makes it really seem like real life. The environment is honestly stunning with beautiful nature and water animations and graphics. Graphics that serve a role in how your battles go mind you. The water isn‚Äôt there to just look pretty, as different attacks effect it and surrounding enemies. Want to use an electric attack on the nearby slimes? Jump in the lake and give them a zap. Or how about crossing over a pond? Easy, freeze it an surrounding enemies for an easy way across and a leg up on battle. 

Everything in this game serves a purpose. The townsfolk you see just walking around give you a great idea about different plot points and will even explain and help you through parts of the game. Even if you‚Äôre someone more interested in the gameplay than the story, every piece of dialogue impacts both. It‚Äôs very well written with incredible voice acting that flows perfectly. 

All in all, I highly recommend this game. It will not disappoint.

review:
It‚Äôs great so far! But there are a few problems, first is that I can‚Äôt see far, because there is a point where the world behind, said point is just a black screen. Which means I can only see the actual world in cutscenes, which are laggy as hell. The you can‚Äôt see enemy‚Äôs in the black void either so I don‚Äôt know what I‚Äôm fighting.
This also makes the stormterror bossfight impossible.

Now onto the cutscenes... I already said that they are laggy as all hell, so I‚Äôm pretty sure I don‚Äôt need to repeat that. But there are also certain cutscenes that don‚Äôt lag, but they also have that endless black void I was talking about. So I can‚Äôt see whatever the cutscene is about.

Another problem I have is that you can‚Äôt see water, it‚Äôs the same black void, and when you get wet there‚Äôs this blinding light that shines from you. It‚Äôs the same thing with torches, there‚Äôs bright light that shines from it when you walk near it, and I can‚Äôt see what I‚Äôm fighting when I‚Äôm near a torch.

But overall those are the only problems I have. The game has amazing potential, but and it‚Äôs kinda like the legend of Zelda breath of the wild, and that‚Äôs an absolute win because that game is amazing, and it inspired a lot of mechanics in a game that I‚Äôm planing to make in the future. I hope that explained why it‚Äôs great that I thought that the game is similar breath of the wild. But anyways that‚Äôs all i think I can say about the game because I can put into words how good this is...

review:
Wow, I‚Äôm incredibly impressed with this game. To have all of this on a game I can play on my phone is insane! Oh, and the coolest part? When I pick up my game on my PC and I‚Äôm exactly where I was when I left the game on my phone! 
Here‚Äôs some other things I appreciate 
‚Ä¢all of the story dialogue and NPC dialogue is actually spoken, which I love. 
‚Ä¢the colors and art style are super good. At first I thought ‚Äúoh this is kinda like BOTW‚Äù and While it looks like it has some inspiration from BOTW, there‚Äôs a completely original feel to the style. It has more of a Anime style feel to it. There are games like Windbound that take too much inspiration from BOTW and it makes me feel more like I‚Äôm playing a clone than a new game. This game feels refreshing.
‚Ä¢The music! I typically play this before bed so it‚Äôs nice to have calming music with some ambient noise while I roam around. Obviously the combat music is good too, but I appreciate the calming roaming music. 
‚Ä¢It actually feels fluid on my phone. Besides frame rates and some graphical changes, it really doesn‚Äôt feel like I‚Äôm ‚Äòswitching‚Äô to a phone game when I get off my PC. I don‚Äôt feel like the phone version is lesser than my PC version other than the frame rates, really. The graphical stuff is mostly just because it‚Äôs a much smaller screen. 
‚Ä¢The combat is great. I like the idea of having multiple characters to swap between and swap out. As well as upgrading weapons. It gives you so much variation so you can make your team exactly how you want. It reminds me a lot of Pokemon to be honest. 
‚Ä¢ And lastly just the little details like if you go idle, your character performs little animations and stuff. 

The only thing I feel a little annoyed with is there‚Äôs no option to ‚Äòlock‚Äô the player icon north on the mini map, rather than the map being locked on north. Makes it a little hard to navigate, since most of the other games I play have it the opposite way. Of course, I can get used to it. 
Also, I‚Äôm not sure if Mounts or Combat Pets are an option, since I‚Äôve only been playing 2 days but if they aren‚Äôt I think that could be a great edition. Or maybe being able to train wild mounts, like BOTW? But with beasts and creatures instead of horses. That‚Äôll give even more variation in the characters. 

I know I sound like a paid reviewer but honestly I just love video games, and I‚Äôm extremely picky. So when I see those details added in, I really appreciate them. There are some games that could be so much better if they just focused more on the little stuff. This is not one of those games. I‚Äôm on day 2 of playing so far and I love it. Can‚Äôt wait for the Switch version.

review:
It is an amazing Surprise and Delight to see what the company MiHoYo is truly capable of producing. With gameplay smooth and sleek, so well thought out that you can play on every character and make your own unique comp for battle and it would always be viable- being a Free to Play player has zero to little disadvantages as there is no true Pay 2 Win features aside from buying more drops, which, don‚Äôt affect your progression in the slightest.

You can really fall in love with the world that the team painstakingly built inch by inch and still not see all that there is, from unique side quests giving you more than satisfying rewards and an interesting story to boot while on the road to your next main story quest. With bosses, dungeons, secrets, treasures and so much to do- it‚Äôs really hard to put the game down.

The only criticism the game truly faces is its pull rates being the lowest of any Gacha game before it, maybe with the slight exclusion being FATE GO. Though the rates are abysmally low, the game itself more than makes up for it and is an absolute MUST download to experience the amazing world and story that it presents.

Despite the main criticism being its Gacha system, the game itself completely and utterly deserves a perfect review score in my opinion as there are hardly any faults I can find with the rest of the game- it‚Äôs story, characters, combat, and the world are all amazingly put together while secrets and side quests keep you going as you explore this vast and amazing world!

review:
Genshin Impact is a ridiculously well-made game. A few minor bugs, like audio clips playing twice in a conversation kind of things, but as far as game design goes, it‚Äôs solid.

The free to play aspect is fairly mellow as well. While I decided to buy the monthly package, I didn‚Äôt feel like I *had to* in order to get weapons and characters. I mostly did to add suppprt to the company and encourage the creation of these kinds of games more.

There‚Äôs no shortage of things to do. You can wander off in any direction and find hidden chests, cool events, random side quests, or even just collect alchemy and cooking ingredients. There‚Äôs no pressure to do any particular thing.

Combat is easier to get into than most Action RPGs I‚Äôve played. I tend to avoid this genre, which is why it took me so long to check out the game, but this game is definitely user friendly in its combat.

It‚Äôs definitely nailed ‚ÄúOpen World‚Äù. Despite there being Invisible Walls, I never felt like I was being restricted on where I could explore.

The gliding mechanic hasn‚Äôt gotten old yet, and I can‚Äôt see it happening anytime soon. I honestly glide anytime I possibly can, even if it just down some stairs.

The art is fantastic, animation fits the aesthetic of the world, and the voice acting is solid.

I don‚Äôt recommend free to play games to a broad audience very much; they‚Äôre typically too genre-focused to appeal to a lot of people. This one is an exception. If you have a device that can run it, it‚Äôs worth checking out for sure. Literally my whole family is playing: our youngest is on her iPad, I‚Äôm on my desktop, my wife and our older daughter are on laptops.

review:
It‚Äôs hard to believe this game is free-to-play, considering how beautifully done everything is. The graphics, the user interface, the gameplay, the story, the music and the voices are top notch. It has many similar elements and gameplay to Zelda: Breath of the Wild, but takes those mechanics and adapts them very well for mobile devices. I am not sure how it would do on a phone as I am playing on an iPad Mini‚ÄîI‚Äôd recommend you use a device with a large enough screen (or just play on PC or console) because you‚Äôre doing yourself a disservice playing on a small screen.

I have played through and completed Prologue II. I have to raise my Adventurer rank to continue the story, but it‚Äôs a good ‚Äúresting‚Äù point as it forces the player to really explore the world and game. The devs really managed to pack so much content and thoughtful details into the game. This is an open world exploration game and wow, there really is tons to explore. You can even set the voice language to English, Japanese, Chinese, or Korean!

Unlike many other MMO games, the user interface is super clean and not overwhelming or intimidating for new or casual players. I really appreciate this and how the game logically and gradually helps you learn how to play. You are never rushed into completing objectives and can really go at your own pace.

The drop rates are a bit stingy, as most apps with random chance are. There are a some characters but there are also a bunch of weapons in the mix. I‚Äôm not sure how I feel about it, but I appreciate that they do give you a basic set of characters that you should be able to work with for a good portion of progress. I feel like if I put in the effort to level and use them I may not need to try to summon characters... BUT because this game is so well done I truly think if you‚Äôre the type to invest in games this would be a great investment.

I‚Äôm really impressed with this game and hope it continues to outdo itself. In an over saturated market of low quality mobile games, this one really shines.

review:
I‚Äôm honestly laughing at how loud people are.
*Possible game spoilers*
This is just my personal approach to the game. And bias in that I play with my best friend. So it‚Äôs all 100x enjoyable.

The story and music is wonderful. The aesthetic of the characters and scenery is breathtaking.

Every character have their own perks, story you can read about, lines they speak. Down to their animation on how they put away their weapons.

I will admit that I‚Äôm one of those people who like to explore before doing my main quests. To which I regret (But I‚Äôll do it again. Responsibly) because I just screw myself over in increasing my world level and then everything just hurts. It‚Äôs just my poor strategy and giggles. And not using my resin because I didn‚Äôt immediately need materials. Game pretty much punished me for going to China while Germany was in peril. (Deserved it)

As for the gacha statistics. As someone who play for the characters, their drop rates is great. As least 1 character is guaranteed per bulk pull (a playable character is always 4* or 5*. 3* and under are weapons) and considering there‚Äôs only about 20 characters released, it‚Äôs great. There‚Äôs also featured characters. Where there‚Äôs a higher drop of that character. They have pity drops where every 90 pulls will guarantee you a 5* character or weapon with an additional 50% chance of actual getting that 5* as the featured character. (I assume if you didn‚Äôt happen to pull a 5* before hand). There‚Äôs a lot of hate every banner btw. For my current example ‚ÄúZhongli‚Äù I‚Äôm hearing a lot of people  saying to buff him, but I like him as is. I wouldn‚Äôt be surprised people will say to nerf him later like all 5* characters. He‚Äôs my main casual DPS. Great support and defense. I chuck that pillar down and it starts chipping damage away at my enemies. It distracts big shields making them turn to the pillar instead of paying attention to me. I then put up my shield for myself as it does an AOE flinching my enemies. I make sure to bunch my enemies together and slam down that meteor and petrify them. Friend is in trouble? Big shield is chasing them? I use the fast normal attack to keep big shield‚Äôs attention on me while they attack from behind. Friend is being ganged up by a mob? I chuck that meteor down right on them. Ez mass petrification.

There‚Äôs also equipping your characters with appropriate accessories and weapons where you can optimize their skills and attacks. This game is strategic. Can‚Äôt just toss something together and expect it to work for higher world levels. Monsters can one shot you if not mindful.

To Mihoyo:
Keep at it! Nothing is wrong with your systems. Just please fix the bugs. Dvalin üò≠ idk if I can handle ghosty neck as I phase into it when trying to climb or switching characters as I try to farm him.

review:
Firstly, for those who are severely criticising this game: WELCOME TO GACHA!!!; or if you‚Äôre having issues playing the game: Keep in mind the game is still very new to the public, and much more is to be added, reorganised, or removed. Also, no game is perfect. Look at your favourite or the most popular video games, for example. They all have bugs and glitches somewhere.
Since the game is so new and miHoYo isn‚Äôt extremely big, their support staff is pretty low for all the people who need to contact them since the release.
To those using mobile devices, I strongly recommend using a computer instead if available. If the game keeps crashing on PC, check the recommended/minimum requirements to run the game.

Now to my review:
I was playing a game and saw the ad for Genshin Impact. It instantly grabbed my attention because it is an open world, action roleplaying game. It has amazing graphics, despite looking cartoonish. The music is extremely beautiful, very well-made and fits the mood perfectly (except that one situation...üòâ  üßç‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è‚öîÔ∏èüå±). The movements are smooth as butter. The story is most interesting (in my opinion, it rivals that of The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim). There are many challenges (achievements, dungeons/boss battles, timed trials, stuff to search for). There are many characters to obtain, each are very distinguishable. The foods and drinks look delicious; I really wish I could try them all ü§§ü§§ü§§. I love everything in this game! As you progress, the game gets more challenging, but if you play it long enough, it gets a lot easier.

We really do have the best travel companionüíô

I do not recommend this game for those who are under the recommended age group (12+).
I highly recommend this game for anyone who qualifies for the recommended age group and loves open world action roleplaying games.

Last thing:
Like I said before, the game is very much a work in progress. If you‚Äôre impatient, do some research how long it takes to create just one of the sceneries. Then, imagine the whole map + your menu + upcoming events.
And then, people demand more once they finish the main story yet not finish everything in each region.

Thank you, miHoYo, Shanghai Miha Touring Film Technology Co., Ltd; Yu-Peng Cheng and HOYO-MIX, voice actors (VA/CV), and all other staff for making this game and keeping the forums clear of disrespectful rubbish.

review:
This is not a mobile game. It doesn‚Äôt feel like it play like one. It‚Äôs particularly demanding storage-wise. All of that in mind, this game is amazing.

It combines elements like a tower-map system, glider, huge open world, and climbing mechanics similar to Zelda: BOTW, but with completely unique combat and story line. This game actually captures the anime-style action a lot of people crave, including simplistic yet expressive graphics.

The small party the player controls, usually consisting of 4-5 characters, resembles the parties we‚Äôre used to seeing in traditional RPG games. Where this deviates from the formula, however, is that only one of your characters is active at a time. In this way, it‚Äôs similar to a hack-slash featuring different classes. With this system, you can switch instantly between them, combining skills individual characters into larger more powerful combinations. This makes combat largely skill and strategy based. Timing does play a part, but isn‚Äôt the main factor like it is in Zelda: BOTW. 

Some other random cool things:
- your weaponry and items never break.
- items and characters are largely acquired through random crates.
- this game is massive, way bigger content-wise than any other mobile game I‚Äôve seen.
- the game is playable and fun without spending real currency.

Less cool things:
- you will probably run out of special currency early on and regaining it will be difficult without spending money.
- the game is designed to be profitable so paying real money gives you a lot more opportunities (not unexpected though, since it‚Äôs a free game!).
- items are obtained at random most of the time, which means you can have a streak of bad luck that wrecks your day.
- the phone storage for this game is huge, which is not surprising considering how massive the game is.

There‚Äôs probably a lot more to add to both of these lists, but I‚Äôm early on in the game so my perspective is a bit limited.

Hope this was helpful!

review:
Genshin Impact is surprisingly good! I always have low expectations for mobile games with Gacha elements but so far I‚Äôve been quite impressed. Not only does it have beautiful art, but it also has an interesting story and entertaining characters. It‚Äôs not aggressively monetized so far (which actually makes me more likely to want to buy things from it, since I feel like I don‚Äôt need to dump tons of money in just to get basic functionality) and there is a surprising amount to explore in the open world. I‚Äôm quite pleased thus far. 

The game takes obvious inspiration from Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild but still feels like it‚Äôs own game and world thanks to the addition of elemental combat magic and Final Fantasy-esque monsters. The JRPG w/ gacha elements reminds me of Xenoblade Chronicles 2 as well. The combat has a decent amount of depth, thanks to all all the elemental reactions and different character classes/weapons. I really like all the puzzles and exploration rewards. It‚Äôs almost a bit overwhelming, as someone who searches obsessively for items lol. There are some frustrating moments (like when I was knocked off a cliff by a group of enemies and couldn‚Äôt get back up to fight them, since their magic attacks kept interrupting my climbing and making me fall) but for the most part combat is pretty fun and gets surprisingly challenging. I‚Äôm still getting the hang of it and finding my preferred playstyle but I‚Äôm having a good time. 

It‚Äôs a little bit uncomfortable to play on my smaller phone (iPhone 11) even though I have small hands, but there are wireless controllers that can be used with iPhones that would probably make it easier/more comfortable to play. I may end up downloading it on a console, if it will let me transfer my account. 

Overall, it‚Äôs a surprisingly good game. It‚Äôs kid friendly as well so far, so you could safely play it with children. The character design is delightful and not overly sexualized, which is a big plus. Is it the best game ever made? No. But for a free to play mobile RPG, I‚Äôm very happy with it.

review:
Intro: 

This game is a beautiful BEAUTIFUL well made game, with outstanding graphics considering it can even be played on mobile devices and amazing plot and voice actors with a variety of characters! You‚Äôve really outdone yourself Mihoyo, and I applaud you for it!! This game is my most favorite to play. 

Gacha: 
But...let‚Äôs talk about the Gacha system, this is the ONLY problem I have with this game. 
The problem is, there is not separate weapon and character banners. I understand most Gacha works like this, but I‚Äôve played MANY that don‚Äôt as well; at the least, please make he drop rate of weapons lower, please. I spend 40$ on this game today and only got one character I didn‚Äôt have who was a 4 star, not to mention it only gave me 20 something pulls and that was with the added bonus, but I‚Äôll get to that in a minute. The drop rate of weapons is horrid, and needs to be toned down or just put into one banner like the one that only drops weapons instead of bleeding into the character banners too. 

On another note, the prices for the amount of things you get is bad too; I understand since this game is completely free you need to make money and that‚Äôs 100% cool with me!! I‚Äôm so down to pay money for stuff in it........ but it‚Äôs very very very low. I think that for 20$ you should at least get 3-4 10x pulls instead of 2 and a half. 

(Or, an alternative would be paying for primogems or fates themselves as another option instead of being forced to only pay for the blue gems which cost a lot just to make primogems which cost a lot to make 1 fate.) I also think the 5$ daily login dropping only 90 primogems a day is kinda low too, maybe 100 a day or enough for just 1 wish? (160) 

Another problem is also doubles: they need to be much lowered if you have a character already, or just give the materials to make another wish when you get the double‚Äî or remove doubles completely‚Äî! There‚Äôs many other options..it just gets annoying when you get a double of a character you have and then get barely anything you can use out of it except for a constellation which isn‚Äôt that important. 

Oh! One more thing: another fix to this all would be to lower the prices of primogems you pay for the fates, or to lower the price of getting primogems in general! Such as just making them more common or have more in missions, Ect. 

Outro: 
That‚Äôs honestly all I had to say!! Thank you so so so so much for creating this game, it brings me a lot of happiness and I seriously love it so much! I just feel like I had to bring out some of the Gacha flaws into the open. <3

review: Genshin Impact is a beautiful open world action rpg with great music and pretty cool combat system with the elemental combos and I absolutely love it for what it does right. So you‚Äôre probably wondering why did I give it one star. Well this game has a HUGE issue currently as of writing this. The resin system. It‚Äôs currently one of the worst energy systems I‚Äôve ever seen from any mobile game and when you take into consideration how much you have to farm mats, exp books, mora, taken books and weapon ascension materials for a SINGLE character. It‚Äôs absolutely ridiculous. The game is great from the moment you start all the way till around AR 30. Until then you probably won‚Äôt notice the resin system because you‚Äôre doing main/side quests and exploring. After you‚Äôve done all that the only thing left to do is farm the things you need for the characters you have because it‚Äôs the only meaningful content for progress. Except you can‚Äôt really do much because those activities cost anywhere from 20-60 resin but you only have 120 each day and it takes 16 hours for a full regeneration. There is no way around this except by spending currency that you would use for character rolls or by outright paying money for diminishing returns for each 60 resin refill (doesn‚Äôt even fully refill). By the time you reach AR 30 you have about 15-20 minutes of content from your dailies to resin usage and then you‚Äôre done. There was a post on the reddit page of this game explaining, mathematically, how badly this system is gating progress for players and how it basically it can take 42 days to level up a character to max and that‚Äôs not even considering the weapons or artifacts you need for them to actually do damage. There is a war of ideas between people who want changes and white knights defending an inherently bad system just because they don‚Äôt want people playing longer than them and getting more from more playtime and because it exists on the mobile market but forget that it also made it into the PC/PlayStation market and most of those players, including myself are very disgusted with the current system. Until changes are made this system is overshadowing all of the good in the game because you can only do 20 minutes of actual progressing content for yourself and what‚Äôs that‚Äôs done all you can is explore and try to find chests where you haven‚Äôt already looked on the map. The game at that point is extremely boring since you can‚Äôt do the content you actually want to do. If you aren‚Äôt at AR 30 I urge you not to spend money on this game until you experience what I‚Äôm talking about because it will change your perspective of this game. This game has such huge potential but it‚Äôs ruined by an unnecessary gating system that serves no purpose other than to limit your progress, try to make you play over a longer period of time but in little bursts, and to extract even more money from their player base in a very underhanded way, even though most of their revenue comes from banners and rolls. I regret spending money on this game because it‚Äôs very likely that it will lose a lot of players by next mont, including myself, if changes aren‚Äôt made soon.

review:
Okayyyyy... I know the title sounds a little... odd... but it‚Äôs true! I play this game often and am always trying to wish but in terms of Priogems, I have no Priogems. I love the art style of this game and it‚Äôs technically just an anime version of Breath of the Wild! All the characters have amazing personalities, and unlike botw, you can actually play as more than one character and you can choose the protagonists gender.

 I feel like I sound weird but honestly, I think the is one of the best games I have on my phone and doubt I‚Äôll ever delete it! I always get excited when there‚Äôs a new event or new Wish banner! I‚Äôm not too far in the game (I‚Äôm only at chapter 2 act 1 while I‚Äôm writing this but I may go to act 2 pretty soon) but I definitely think that if your CRAVING a game like this, this is a pretty good game! I‚Äôll say Honkai Impact is a pretty good game too but I haven‚Äôt played that yet! and I‚Äôm also waiting very HARDCORE for the Ballad in Goblets (or however that was written it‚Äôs been a bit) to come back, cause I BADLY want Venti even though my chances are most likely lower than 20%. MiHoYo, if you guys are reading this, I just wanna say how much I appreciate how much hard work you guys put in to this game! 

On the map screen Teyvat looks small but when exploring it‚Äôs SO BIG! probably the biggest map I‚Äôve ever seen! So if anybody who wants to buy the game is reading this, I‚Äôm happy I introduced you a bit to this absolutely awesome game! I should also mention that the voice actors are super good and just make the game a lot more lively than if there wasn‚Äôt! It‚Äôs a great game and I highly suggest getting is!

review:
Genshin Impact. A phenomenal game that went beyond my expectations. I‚Äôve been playing for just two days but every moment has got me absorbed in the game. To start with my experience, I was skeptical at first because it sounded like another regular fantasy game and it seemed overhyped the past few months. I decided to install it a week ago because I thought there has to be a reason why there‚Äôs so much craze for it. Little did I know, Genshin Impact would be and is the FIRST mobile game that has made me excited to play it and impressed me for being such a well developed game story-wise, gameplay-wise, and graphic-wise, beyond my expectations.

The character design and the graphics are what caught my attention at first. But, I will say that the first hour playing was definitely a lot to take in, with all the buttons, options, character info and abilities, inventory, and quests, but as I continued playing I got used to it and it has been A BLAST afterwards.

I love this game, however a major issue is that I get motion sickness, dizziness, and nausea playing this game. Although I beared it the first hour yesterday, and the last 4 hours today, I realized that I can‚Äôt play this game for more than 15-30 minutes without getting nauseous and feeling dizzy, causing me to take a break from my entire iPad for a long time. I as well as many other players who experienced the same thing even on console and PC, can‚Äôt enjoy this game to its full potential because of this reason and I believe it has to do with the FOV(field of view) being too small or very close up, the motion blur in the background, the camera automatically adjusting itself and moving on its own whenever the character moves/runs, the resolution, the sensitivity being a bit too high even on lowest setting (1), etc, and there is currently nothing we can do about it.

I‚Äôve been playing mobile games for two years specifically first person shooting games like CODM, Critical Ops, and PUBGM. I find that even when first playing it, I didn‚Äôt experience dizziness or sickness, something I usually experience in other games like open world or third person games, like Minecraft. The reason for that is because the FOV in these shooting games are larger, I assume.

Another issue is the major battery consumption. I do play on an iPad that works well with its battery life and does not drain. But, I was playing today with full battery and it depleted to 10% within 4 hours. It‚Äôs alarming that this application consumed 84% of my device‚Äôs battery, without the usage of other apps. Please fix this issue with battery.

It‚Äôs very unfortunate that many Genshin players have experienced motion sickness to the point where it is unbearable to play, and there is no way of changing the settings to cope with this. I wish that the FOV and resolution is bigger and the camera does not automatically moving around, etc. and the aspect of the motion, graphics, fov and resolution are fixed ASAP, and we have the options in the settings to change these things. 

I also hope we can move our control buttons around the screen (hud) since some of us do play with four or more fingers. The issue is with the settings‚Äîmaybe y‚Äôall haven‚Äôt yet developed them or didn‚Äôt plan to, but I do highly suggest there are more options in the settings, all coming from a player‚Äôs perspective of the game. Nonetheless, Genshin Impact has definitely proved itself for being an amazing game of quality, creativeness, graphics, gameplay, movement, abundance of characters, interesting storylines, a unique aesthetic, and I see all of your hard work put into this game.

To the developers and team of Genshin Impact, I do hope this lengthy but honest review is taken into consideration and these issues are looked over and resolved in the near future so I and many other players can enjoy and experience this game to the fullest. There will only continue to be much work and needed improvements in the future, so I do want to see these fixes as I believe they are of importance and would make the game much, much better than it already is. So thank you for this amazing game!!!!

review:
I do find this game to be very fun. I‚Äôm a huge fan of gacha games (for those who don‚Äôt know, those are games where you spend in-game currency to do pulls on special events to try and get stuff like playable characters and weapons, all at different rarities), they have a fair system where if you get character copies you can use them to give that character special buffs, the game looks amazing for a mobile, and the controls are fairly comfortable. While you can pay money for in game currency to do more pulls or refill energy for certain quests or special bosses, the game is very free-to-play friendly, despite what others might say. You can easily beat the game and fully enjoy it with just the starter characters as long as your half way decent with the combat. The game also has a pity system that‚Äôs, at the very least, better than most with every 90 pulls being a guaranteed 5-star character/item and, depending on the special banner you summoned from, the first 5-star you get has a 50% chance to be the featured item and the next one will be guaranteed. I haven‚Äôt paid any money on the game, gotten 2 5-stars, and haven‚Äôt even done 90 pulls yet (but that‚Äôs my personal experience considering that they have a 0.6% drop rate).

But of course, being the mobile version, it will be a little clunky compared to the console and pc versions. *WARNING* This game will practically incinerate your phone. Your phone will become hot to the touch after a couple of minutes depending on your graphics settings. The game does also have some frame rate and crashing, these can also be fixed by lowering the graphics settings (very low, low, normal, high, very high). On the bright side though, this game has, BY FAR, the best auto save mechanic I‚Äôve ever seen in a game. This game will save your exact location and status of your characters, account, progress, etc. no matter what.
The main reason I didn‚Äôt give this game a 5-star rating instead of a 4-star one was because once you beat the game, there‚Äôs not really much to do except explore or do whatever additional story quests or events that hat added on periodically.

And now to address some other complaints I‚Äôve noticed in these ratings:

‚ÄúYou need to give email/password from google or Facebook or gaming center, etc.‚Äù
-While true... get over yourself, no one cares.

‚ÄúGame won‚Äôt start‚Äù
-I haven‚Äôt experienced this or heard anyone else complain about it

‚ÄúGame erasing progress‚Äù
-Again, like the last one, I personally haven‚Äôt experienced this nor heard this from anyone else in the community.

‚ÄúGame doesn‚Äôt provide controller support‚Äù
-True. But you people realize there are like 20 games on the entire App Store that have controller support, right?

review:
I absolutely love this game overall! It offers a beautiful open-world with varied combat styles, quests, and treasures to be uncovered. It‚Äôs obvious they put a lot of effort into this game and it‚Äôs awesome that it‚Äôs free. But for as much as I love the game, here are some of my main issues (summary at the end): 

One, the leveling up system is a little too hard as you go on. The easiest way to do it is using cards, but you don‚Äôt get too many of the higher level ones so it makes it a lot tougher to gain levels. This wouldn‚Äôt be such a problem if not for the game encouraging that you switch your character pretty often. You can concentrate on leveling up just one character if you want, but then you‚Äôll likely be switching to other lower-level characters when the time comes.

This leads me into two: you can only play as one person at a time despite having a party. It would be really cool to have the other characters in your party fight alongside you, and then you could just switch between your main. It would be extremely useful when fighting multiple enemies. This wouldn‚Äôt bother me as much if the elemental system, and therefore switching, wasn‚Äôt as emphasized.

Three, the game gives you information on enemies, combat, etc. you come across as the game goes on, but as far as I can tell there‚Äôs no way to actually refer back to it. I‚Äôm not sure if this is something that maybe gets unlocked later on, but it would be especially useful to have as a beginner or returning player. 

Four, the co-op system should probably be available earlier. A lot of people would probably want to play this game just for that function, but it isn‚Äôt unlocked until you‚Äôve leveled up your adventure rank I think to level 15.

TLDR; leveling up is difficult, you can only switch between characters instead of having them all deployed at once, you don‚Äôt seem to be able to refer back to information you get throughout the game, and co-op should be offered sooner.

review:
4/5 stars is probably more than I should be giving this game. Don‚Äôt get me wrong, it‚Äôs absolutely gorgeous and fun. I play on both PC and mobile for a couple hours before bed each night. The story is engaging and the characters are quite entertaining (well, as entertaining as they can get with English voice acting).

My issue is the gacha. I understand that the developers need to make money... but this game could have been better if it was a different form of payment. I would have been fine having to pay for a sub or a one time fee of $30+ for a BOTW-like experience on my phone/PC.

Sadly the mobile market relies on whales to run. Everyone knows that. Rich people or people with poor money management issues will spend thousands on games like these... they foot the bill for average players. But again... I would prefer it be a ‚Äúplay a trial for free‚Äù and you can pay a one time payment of X amount to be able to just play to get the characters, and play to get the gear, and maybe have SOME wait times but are never too intrusive to the gameplay (something like Bravely Default, where it only serves to help you more and is never really necessary just to beat the base story).

I‚Äôm sure the game won‚Äôt get better in terms of drop rates. It‚Äôs really fun in its honeymoon phase but unless you‚Äôre willing to reach that point of only logging on to do dailies after a bit (or spending money), I don‚Äôt recommend playing more than what you‚Äôre willing to.

I‚Äôm not even saying this game is bad, it‚Äôs sincerely not. The graphics are good (play on an iPhone 8 and up, it will not run well on older devices and in many cases won‚Äôt even open for those using a 7+ or less in terms of iPhone), the gameplay is fun for it being a hack and slash, and the grind isn‚Äôt too awful at first... just don‚Äôt expect the game to be fun forever. A wall will be hit at some point as they press for more money over time.

review: Genshin Impact starts off really great. There is a lot of stuff to do in the world and the map is huge. This game looks good, has a great open world, great characters etc. I really like playing this game but as for how long probably not long. Once you reach around Adventure Rank 30 the game drastically starts to slow down as you have completed a majority of the main story quests, explored a majority of the map and start nitpicking for experience from world quests, chests to bump you up to the next rank or spending resin on domains/bosses. Their resin system is probably the biggest flaw as of right now. It is seriously time gated to where an average gamer can get on do the daily commissions, burn their resin, go to work, come home and still not have the max limit of resin. When it comes to rolling for characters this is probably the worst of the worst when it comes to the rates. The ‚Äúpity system‚Äù is great for 4-star characters but absolutely garbage for 5-star characters. If you pay $$$ to roll characters you are looking at $200 just to get a 5-star character from 90 rolls which is their pity system if you are not lucky. That is just for one character. Which each character has a constellation that is upgradable from duplicate characters. As for the characters it requires A LOT to fully max out one character to the point where it is best to only focus upgrading 2-3 characters at one time because they will use up everything you have and then some. Upon release as well when players were getting all this free stuff and thinking this is awesome. Codes were released for people to claim primo gems (what you use to roll for characters or resin refills if you are an f2p player). These codes were unable to be used by console players on PS4. They were only redeemable by PC and Mobile. Since then there have been some events here and there mainly around logging in and claiming rewards which are nice but considering how far those rewards actually go when it comes to doing anything in the game is really lacking. There also was a co op event where you collect cubes and fight waves of enemies. This event was more of a grind it out and never touch it again than an enjoyable event with replay value. Also, it was horribly optimized to where players would glitch out either running in place or unable to pickup/deposit the cubes. This is a really great game and can be really fun early game but late game it is more resource management making it hard for Streamers/YouTubers to do their JOB for long periods of time. Really great game but lackluster events, disappointing rewards and even worse management.

title: Genshin Impact iOS14.0.1

review:
The game overall is very fun to play and I make sure to play daily.

I feel the game isn‚Äôt very considerate of the free to play players. Primogems become very scarce so it gets much harder to do any wishes. I believe Mihoyo needs to start catering to the f2p players soon as well, because they are more valuable than the p2p at the end of the day.

1.1 Update:

    I was also excited for the quality of life features in the 1.1 update but locking all of those items behind the Reputation System was a bad choice. It‚Äôs going to take months to grind up enough reputation in each area to get the rewards, and by the time you do get the rewards you won‚Äôt need them anymore. (You can also just look up the Genshin Interactive Map to find all the chests and anemoculus/geoculus anyways, so the rewards are essentially useless) 
    There should be weekly missions and bounties for BOTH Liyue and Teyvat so that you can build reputation in both places at once, instead of choosing only one to grind at a time.

Customer Service:

Overall customer service responses are very slow.
Also, I encountered a bug in the game and customer service didn‚Äôt help me, and the session was left to expire, meaning I have to contact them again (ugh).
I completed a commission but didn‚Äôt unlock the achievement for it, and instead of helping me they talked about the Welkin Blessing. (I hope they weren‚Äôt dodging my issue on purpose, because it seems like they were)

We‚Äôre really lucky this game is free, and there are so many great things about it and I really enjoy playing the game but some aspects of it are starting to wear me out. Hopefully there will be more consideration for players customer service wise and game wise.
title: Slow Customer Service, Needs More Primogems, Great Overall

review: It took me 2 minutes of playing this game to realize it‚Äôs an exact copy of legend of Zelda, breath of the wild. The game starts with some exposition that I don‚Äôt remember, and you get to pick a character. You spawn on a beach with an incredibly annoying rat fairy that won‚Äôt stop talking. As I‚Äôm walking up the beach, I see a lizard that looks almost identical to the lizards you‚Äôd find in BOTW. Just like in BOTW, you can pick up the lizards and basically anything else you find. I was like, ‚Äúhuh, ok, maybe it‚Äôs just inspiration‚Äù and I didn‚Äôt think much of it. Then from what I can remember, you learn how to run. When you run you use up stamina, and I‚Äôm pretty sure the stamina wheel is an exact copy and paste from BOTW. You can also do all the other things you can do in BOTW, like climb and jump a very small distance. You then walk up to a hill, and at this point, I know what‚Äôs going on. Almost the exact same layout for the landscape was used. To get down the hill you have to walk down a path going down the side of the mountain, just like BOTW. There is a large castle in the background, just like BOTW. Even the opening shot of the camera panning across the landscape, is exactly. Like. BOTW. There‚Äôs also a large tower in the middle of the map, that allows you to see a mini map. Wonder where that‚Äôs from? If you hadn‚Äôt already guessed, it‚Äôs BOTW. There was also some kind of element thing that was boring so I didn‚Äôt pay attention to it, but I guess that‚Äôs at least something different. As I walk away from the tower, I see some monsters that have the exact same spiky thingys coming out of the ground that BOTW has, and the monsters have the exact same weapons as the bokoblins from BOTW. At this point, I had decided that I‚Äôm not going to waste my time playing a game I‚Äôve already played. In conclusion, this game is a complete rip off of legend of Zelda breath of the wild. I‚Äôm honestly surprised Nintendo hasn‚Äôt sued this company for this yet. Also, I looked through the reviews, and nobody seems to be noticing this. The only possible reason for this I can think of is that the devs are deleting reviews that bring up this point.

review:
I love this game; it truly scratches all the itches as a player: gacha dopamine spikes, lots of different aspects of a character to level, and above all, a writing and design team that is obviously truly passionate about their game, characters and world. 

But, there does seem to be a fatal wrench shoved in the gears of the game; the team behind updates and changes to the system that the player base has been absolutely screaming about for a full month since the games release. I won‚Äôt get into them here, I don‚Äôt have nearly enough space, but to summarize; the team seems adamant to make sure that outside of story updates, you have about 15 minutes of enjoyable content twice a day if you‚Äôre lucky. Commissions > two world bosses>one or two dungeons and poof, you‚Äôll be wandering around begging for something interesting to do. To be clear; I have spent money on this game, and I do not regret it; but, with the devs most recent response to the thousands of player surveys is anything to judge by, it‚Äôs currently unlikely I‚Äôll be making any other purchases. If these factors change, I‚Äôd love to change my rating to five times it‚Äôs current amount.
To summarize: I‚Äôm fine with the terrible gacha rates. I‚Äôm fine with the horribly expensive gems. I‚Äôm fine with long update cycles, and I‚Äôm fine with the low drop rate on high rarity materials, as well as the incredible material and fiscal cost of leveling anything in Teyvat. 
Just let me play your game, Mihoyo.

review:
The game it self it ‚Äúfine‚Äù well there is sooooooo much issue with. One of the biggest issue now is the level progression and rewards failure. U won‚Äôt feel it until u hit around lv 45. Because then u don‚Äôt really have anything to do to increase ur level. Furthermore no one want to admit it but once u hit certain lv your world lv increase. World lv 6 and lv 7 doesn‚Äôt have any significant reward change whatsoever ever. There is a thing called risk and reward, and who‚Äôs failed in every aspect of it. World 7 has more loved enemies than lv6 but the reward stay the same, and players need to get to world lv 8 to do so tht is equal to lv 55. Now if u don‚Äôt know the difficulty to actually get tht lv ask anyone around u who play Genshin how hard is to get a lv after lv45
Second issue is the stamina system. Let just say if u r a free to play player, u will not be able to get much resource to train a lot of new characters. The game offers you different characters and new ones came out like every 2 week. If u are at late game u just can‚Äôt effectively get a new character and rapidly getting tht character to the lv of your domains. 
Last is we‚Äôre I have the most issue with, is the arrogance of the puplisher and developer Mihoyo itself. Just remember this if there is any bug tht benefit to players like the ‚Äúmushroom bug‚Äù, ‚ÄúXingqu and Barbara‚Äôs stamina bug‚Äù they will fix it in a day. Now if it‚Äôs a bug tht won‚Äôt benefits to players like the ‚Äúice tree terrain hole‚Äù ‚Äúwind dragon‚Äôs neck‚Äù they won‚Äôt fix it until next version update. And on top of that I asked for a receipt they literally disconnected me from their customer service. So I will not even consider pay another penny for any of this company at all

review:
Assuming the anime-ness of the world isn‚Äôt a turnoff for you, there lies a very competent game inside. If you‚Äôve played BotW before, then it‚Äôs easy to see why most people call this game an anime Breath of the Wild, though it isn‚Äôt just a clone.
For one, the combat in this game is closer to NieR: Automata than Zelda, with the ability to switch between party members during combat. This game also has a progression system similar to JRPGs like Xenoblade Chronicles 2, where doing quests and finding new items and locations in the world rewards you with EXP.
The gacha elements might be a controversial element for some, but as far as I can see it‚Äôs not necessary to use it to progress through the story.
Another thing about this game on iOS is how well this game runs. Granted, i‚Äôm playing this game on the latest 2020 iPad Pro but even then i‚Äôm able to play this game with its graphics settings cranked up to their max and am still able to get a consistent 60fps, and it certainly is one of the best looking mobile games i‚Äôve seen on the app store.
My biggest gripe with the game by far however, is the lack of gamepad support. It‚Äôs disappointing to see a major game such as this launch without any support for an external controller, especially as this game is also available on PC and PS4. Touch controls are fine and it would be a bit weird to use a controller on a smaller device, but having no support for it nearly a month after it‚Äôs official launch is bizarre.
Also of note is the small ‚Äòquirks‚Äô this game sometimes has. Whether it be small gaffs in scripting or odd dialogue it‚Äôs certainly noticeable but it‚Äôs not gamebreaking, at least none that i‚Äôve encountered.
Overall though this is still a very good game, and especially for a free game it‚Äôs certainly worth the try.
title: Good, Fun Game

review:
As someone who‚Äôs still only in the very beginning of the game, I‚Äôll share my impression so far by saying that Genshin is a game with a lot to offer; amazing visuals, fantastic voice acting, a fun storyline, a colorful setting, ample customization, straightforward but challenging combat, and overall gameplay that puts other IOS apps to shame. As far as I can tell, it‚Äôs forgiving to newcomers, but still fun for more avid gamers, or anyone looking for an engaging pastime.

That said, the experience of playing Genshin is seriously hampered by a few major bug on IOS. The first (relatively more minor) one is related to the cutscenes. Now, what I‚Äôm able to see of them, the cutscenes look great, but more often it‚Äôs irritating experience rife with buffering, interruptions, skipped portions, and on a few occasions the scenes outright crash the app. Just to get through the scenes, I have to strategically leave the game and then return after 30 seconds. 

Very annoying, but tolerable if it wasn‚Äôt in addition to a bigger problem, namely an odd ‚Äúvoid effect‚Äù on the sky and moderately distant surroundings. Practically anything not directly in front of the avatar is compelling obscured by pitch black shadows, including certain integral scenes, water features, and enemies, including the Storm dragon. As a matter of fact, I‚Äôm at the boss fight now and it‚Äôs honestly impossible to surpass because the entire screen is shrouded in darkness. Obviously, something is off, and after some research I‚Äôve found that I‚Äôm not the only one having this issue. 

Finally, there‚Äôs another bug having to do with obnoxious, glaring orbs of light which obscure the avatar and even enemies anytime you step into water, or even in select combat scenarios. Which, as one might imagine, makes fighting enemies a whole lot harder. 

Despite my complaints, it should be telling that I‚Äôve stuck to the game if with its issues. It‚Äôs honesty worth it, and even better if you don‚Äôt encounter the same problems. As of now, I just hope the developers will I find time to fix things. If they get there, I‚Äôll change my review to 5 stars.

review:
As a game producer in mobile for over 10 years, I‚Äôm amazed when games like this come across my radar. It just hits all the right notes.  The art direction and style is stunning. The music is enchanting. The battle system feels very ‚ÄúTales of‚Äù series-like which combines well with an open world adventure.

If you loved Nintendo‚Äôs Zelda: Breath of the Wild it takes a lot of inspiration from that and builds upon it with depth from a lot of good ideas that other open world RPGs get right.

The two things that I‚Äôm not enjoying. One is its best feature is apparently co-op multiplayer and it‚Äôs locked away behind Adventure Rank 16. Which takes a lot of gameplay time to get to. I even discussed this with a group of game designers and game product professionals and we‚Äôre all in agreement and baffled why such a great feature is locked away until later in the game. Just let us adventure this world with our friends! From a business standpoint this is a unique selling point of this game that stands it apart from those calling it a Zelda clone, but its locked away behind a big grind.

The second aspect I‚Äôm not enjoying and this is a personal preference is Paimon. I grew up on anime as a kid and into my 20‚Äôs back in the 1990‚Äôs, but I also grew out of anime and don‚Äôt watch it much anymore unless it is fresh and groundbreaking. The moment I hear a cutesy spoil brat sounding child character is like nails on a chalkboard. I just can‚Äôt take much of it anymore. It‚Äôs what made Xenoblade Chronicles 2 such torture to complete as a game and mainly why I don‚Äôt play anime styled games anymore because they ALWAYS add a Paimon-like character. It‚Äôs obnoxious on the deepest level for me and seriously team, if you are reading this, I‚Äôd gladly pay you $5,000 for the ability to disable Paimon. You think I‚Äôm kidding, but its such a trite anime trope and there other voice directions to go in than that after 30 years of anime watching.

Overall, I really love this game and I love how this game is cross-platform. So if you intend to switch between playing this on your phone, tablet, and PC then sign up with a miHoYo account first. If you sign-up up using other methods first it‚Äôll likely force you into a position to start over in order to play cross-platform.
title: Stunning game, but its best feature is held back

review: This game is getting praised way too much right now. Definitely has potential and very fun gameplay but the pull rates are abysmal and the game is just too unfinished right now. Around AR30 it becomes way less fun as the story just stops at a random point and the systems in place such as the resin system deter you from even actually playing the game. 120 resin cap with some bosses costing 60 resin and a full resin recharge taking ~14 hours. And the drops aren‚Äôt even that good. Leveling and ascending at this point is just unfun and the devs don‚Äôt even let you grind anything. I reached the point where I can‚Äôt upgrade my characters because I can‚Äôt farm materials because I don‚Äôt have any resin left. It‚Äôs like they don‚Äôt want you to play their game. Chests are just full of junk that don‚Äôt help at all at that point too. Co-op is a buggy mess and there‚Äôs not really a good reason to do it at all, besides some stupid co-op puzzles around the world. This game really doesn‚Äôt deserve a 1* review but neither does it deserve a 4* or even 5* currently. It‚Äôs amazing up until around AR25 but after that it feels like the devs are trying to ruin your fun. I am amazed this has such good reviews right now and I really hope the devs can still make this a great game. Even if they just fix the resin system that would be awesome. Hopefully I can come back and give this game a 5* review because it really has the potential. Really hope I can come back after the 1.1 and 1.2 patches and say that my complaints have been fixed.

review:
I grinded for over a week collecting primogems. You get a 0.6% chance of getting a five star, so you‚Äôre lucky to even get one in the time this game has been released (unless you reroll). I got a five star today. It was a five star weapon that was absolutely, utterly useless to me. I have no use for it. I didn‚Äôt want it. 

Absolutely greedy and trashy. It shouldn‚Äôt be this miserable to pull a five star. There is absolutely no excuse for this. This game would be lovely if it weren‚Äôt for the greediness of the devs. You barely get any primogems, not unless you fork over obscene amounts of money of course. There are so many other gacha games who are generous. Why? You‚Äôre going to turn off your player base with this crap. I get that this is how gacha is but as someone who‚Äôs played many gacha games this is the greediest I‚Äôve seen by far. Who wants to play this game if 70% of the better characters are locked away and virtually impossible to get unless you‚Äôre insanely lucky?

Rant over. This game is so much fun and has so much going for it but the sheer impossibility of getting even ONE five star is utterly insane to me. Again, I understand how gacha games go. But the rates plus how little primogems we‚Äôre able to obtain makes this game just not worth playing. Don‚Äôt bother with this game if you have a gambling addiction, either. This is just straight up dangerous. Until the devs decide to fix the rates or at least make the primogem distributions more plentiful, I don‚Äôt see this game lasting very long for a majority of the player base. Fix it. It‚Äôs so disappointing and a waste.

review:
I‚Äôd like to say off the bat that this game is beyond what I had expected for a free to play game in multiple areas, it had gave me many hours of content already and I will enjoy this game to come in the near future as long as I don‚Äôt feel like the game is going in a awful direction and as is, it might if the resin system isn‚Äôt fixed in some way.

If you use Reddit or are some platform that is social and is about Genshin impact you probably know many are upset with the resin system. The problem with it is that you can barely do much or get much for the amount you spend and must wait. This mainly affects those that have gathered most chests and completed the story such as myself when we‚Äôre at the end game and have nothing else but to grind out artifacts and mats for various things. An issue here is there are tons of things you need to make so little progress with the resin you will have available due to how slow resin regenerates and since you don‚Äôt get extra by completing a daily or other source that is consistent throughout the day.

Many will say ‚Äúthis is a gacha/F2P game...‚Äù and my rebuttal is that yes this is a gacha/F2P game but it‚Äôs also one that is on console and PC and that alone should not warrant it as an excuse to let slide by. The energy system of this game is far worse than many other mobile games I‚Äôve played, in others I could get extra energy from dailies or simply by logging in or other means allowing me to play for more than 10 minutes. This poses a bigger issue that this is on console and PC that it may take minutes to boot up a pc or console to log in, in the first place, and that you don‚Äôt boot up a pc or consoles for get comfortable to play a game for 10 minutes. 

I will leave it here but I encourage many to stop giving this game a pass just cause ‚Äúit‚Äôs a gacha/F2P game‚Äù cause that is a poor excuse seeing as other games have the same system yet I can log in for much longer and get far more done than I can in this game. This game is tons of fun but right now it‚Äôs being summed down by a system that will make many stop playing in the future and potentially many customers down the road with this system as is.

PS: This game has many more problems that should be addressed besides just the resin system but for now this is one of the bigger ones and shouldn‚Äôt affect newer players too badly till after they complete the story so far.

review:
The amount of good things is too long to list, but each of those things are severely overshadowed by the hollow feeling and buyers remorse one feels spending any amount of money or after playing for a couple/few weeks. 

A fundamental flaw w/Genshin is their progression/summoning system. 

Yes you get chars, yes all are usable, yes the game front loads and yes you can probably reroll for 1-2 5*‚Äôs albeit a massive nuisance. 

The issue is being able to build these things as gear drops & gear stats are plagued with disproportunatly awful RNG outcomes. Beyond that- your account level scales passively as you play and the difficulty of the game scales as well- if you were not fortunate enough to get adaquate gear drops within a given time frame the game will gradually scale beyond your ability to keep up... in other words- the dungeons you grind for gear may eventually become the very reason you can no longer handle fighting in those very same dungeons, depending on how lucky your gear drops were within a given window.  (At least one my experience so far) 

As for the summoning, we‚Äôll just forget that beyond week one. This is with out a doubt one of the most disappointing aspects of Genshin for me. If there is a summoning system I would like to use it on occasion, but thanks to their progression system it would take you nearly a year to earn enough resources to reach the point you have a 50% shot to get the featured 5* banner unit. Iirc 40 currency per day, 160 for a single pull, takes 14,400 to hit pity, once you do there‚Äôs no guarantee it‚Äôll even be the banner unit. To their credit- each 10 pulls gives a guaranteed 4* weapon or character, which is nice- though probably a less than enjoyable outcome given the amount of time it takes to reach that goal. 

This was with out a doubt the most enjoyable first week I‚Äôve ever experienced in a mobile game to date, unfortunately the level of disappointment, that‚Äôs more than likely, via summoning and gear acquisition - may leave you with too little motivation to even play eventual unlockable/new content. 

If you are they type of player that enjoys slow progression models and does not mind fairly limited access to essential dungeons this may be the perfect game for you.

review:
I love all aspects of this game except the monetization, which is the only reason I can‚Äôt give it 5 stars. You may want to stay away from this game if you have ever had a gambling addiction or think you may be at risk for developing one.

That said, the game world is absolutely beautiful. The open world exploration is similar to Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild. It‚Äôs fun to explore the open game world and enjoy the views. The music is excellent and really adds to the finely crafted ambience. There are plenty of things to collect, puzzles to solve, enemies to fight, achievements to unlock, and quests to complete. 

The main story is engaging and the playable characters are distinct and memorable, each with their own backstory and personality quirks. The combat is fast paced and strategically interesting. The combat systems of elemental interactions, character swapping, the variety of character abilities, and equippable weapons and artifacts combine to provide interesting options to play around with and experiment with different strategies.

Overall, an excellent game. But still, I‚Äôll reiterate my warning from above: you may want to stay away from this game if you have ever had a gambling addiction or think you may be at risk for developing one. They give you a lot of free chances with the in-game gambling: the ‚Äòwish‚Äô system. And having that taste of rolling the dice might draw you in if you have ever or could potentially have a gambling problem, so proceed with caution.

review: I have been following this game since beta launch and was very impressed by so many streamers highlighting the positives of this game as being groundbreaking and genre defining especially as a Gacha game. Unfortunately, this game did not live up to all the hype and it in fact was disappointing. With global launches other games have been extremely more generous. For starters. But this game isn't at all giving with its launch rewards, and it is heavily geared towards the pay to play gamers. With that being said the players that pay will be disappointed! The rates for obtaining good characters and the in game currency is outrageously bad and expensive. The monthly pass also is too much money for too little rewards. Besides terribly low rates, the gameplay is a bit awkward. Besides the expensive in game currency, and awkward clunky controls, I was under the impression that this game would have a luscious open world sprawling with monsters. That‚Äôs what was so heavily marketed about this game anyways. What a letdown! This game has an open world albeit a barren one. With the exception of the few slimes there‚Äôs not that many monsters. So you basically run around a huge open world... With extremely low drop rates, expensive summons, a bad monthly pass, and few monsters to do battle with this game offers nothing new to the market besides a new for an initial product for a  PVE gacha game. Tech otakus didn‚Äôt save the world. Instead, tech otakus got greedy and created a sub par game. #SorryNotSorry.
title: Tech Otakus get GREEDY

review:
I love this game, because with the amazing graphics, lovable characters, and detailed story, it really does make you feel like you‚Äôre part of another world. BUT THEY NEED TO FIX THE CRASHING ISSUE. It crashes every 15 min or so. I have an iPhone 8, which is by no means old in 2020.

For anyone already playing the game, you‚Äôll understand my pain when I tell you I rage-deleted the game after a certain thing happened: I accidentally increased to world level 3 before ascending my characters to handle that level (btw, it‚Äôs unfair that they don‚Äôt allow you to bring it back down). Instead I had to grind a bit to strengthen their weapons. Started fighting an Oceanid, which I had struggled with before. Every few seconds, I had to restore health or revive my characters, that thing was so tough. I used up more than half of everything I had. Then, just when two in my team were dead, and I had to wait a few more seconds to use another revive, the game had to ‚ÄúRECONNECT TO SERVER‚Äù which often happens at random, but especially when you‚Äôre afk. I freaked out, wondering where I would respawn...

The game brought me back to before I had even approached the Oceanid‚Äôs platform, but    THREE OF MY CHARACTERS WERE DEAD.

COMPLETELY UNACCEPTABLE. After that I was like, ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs it. I‚Äôm done.‚Äù And deleted it. Maybe I‚Äôll come back to it someday, maybe in a few months when I‚Äôve calmed down and I can‚Äôt remember why a silly video game made me so upset in the first place. But right now I just can‚Äôt do it. If I want to know what happens next in the story, I might just watch someone else‚Äôs walkthrough.

Someone please fix this, because it‚Äôs making the game unplayable.
title: DELETED‚ÄîALWAYS CRASHING
